batoid
  • Coordinate Systems
  • View page source

Coordinate SystemsÔÉÅ

Batoid uses coordinate systems to track the positions and orientations of rays and surfaces. By using coordinate systems, one only ever has to define how surfaces behave when their vertexes are at the origin (0,0,0); relocating the surface to a non-origin vertex is accomplished by transforming coordinates.

There are two parts to a coordinate system in batoid:

  • the origin, which specifies in global coordinates to the location of (0, 0, 0) in local coordinates, and

  • the orientation, which specifies how the local x, y, and z axes are rotated with respect to the global axes.

class batoid.CoordSys(origin=None, rot=None)[source]ÔÉÅ

A coordinate system against which to measure surfaces or rays.

Coordinate systems consist of an origin and a rotation. The origin attribute specifies where in 3D space the current coordinate system‚Äôs origin lands in the global coordinate system. The rotation rot specifies the 3D rotation matrix to apply to the global coordinate axes to yield the axes of the this coordinate system.

Parameters:

  • origin (ndarray of float, shape (3,)) ‚Äì Origin of coordinate system in global coordinates.

  • rot (ndarray of float, shape (3, 3)) ‚Äì Rotation matrix taking global axes into current system axes.

property xhatÔÉÅ

Orientation of local x vector in global coordinates.

Type:

ndarray of float, shape (3,)

property yhatÔÉÅ

Orientation of local y vector in global coordinates.

Type:

ndarray of float, shape (3,)

property zhatÔÉÅ

Orientation of local z vector in global coordinates.

Type:

ndarray of float, shape (3,)

shiftGlobal(dr)[source]ÔÉÅ

Return new CoordSys with origin shifted along global axes.

dr (ndarray of float, shape (3,)) ‚Äì Amount to shift in meters.

Returns:

Return new CoordSys with origin shifted along local axes.

dr (ndarray of float, shape (3,)) ‚Äì Amount to shift in meters.

Returns:

Convert vector(s) from local to global coordinates.

v (ndarray of float, shape (n, 3)) ‚Äì Vector(s) in local coordinates.

Returns:

vv (ndarray of float, shape (n, 3)) ‚Äì Vector in global coordinates.

Convert vector(s) from global to local coordinates.

Parameters:

v (ndarray of float, shape (n, 3)) ‚Äì Vector(s) in global coordinates.

Returns:

vv (ndarray of float, shape (n, 3)) ‚Äì Vector in local coordinates.

rotateGlobal(rot, rotCenter=(0, 0, 0), coordSys=None)[source]ÔÉÅ

Return new CoordSys rotated with respect to global axes.

Parameters:

  • rot (ndarray of float, shape (3, 3)) ‚Äì Rotation matrix to apply.

  • rotCenter (ndarray of float, shape (3,)) ‚Äì Point about which to rotate.

  • coordSys (CoordSys) ‚Äì Coordinate system in which rotCenter is specified.

Returns:

CoordSys

rotateLocal(rot, rotCenter=(0, 0, 0), coordSys=None)[source]ÔÉÅ

  • rotCenter (ndarray of float, shape (3,)) ‚Äì Point about which to rotate.

class batoid.CoordTransform(fromSys, toSys)[source]ÔÉÅ

Transformation between two coordinate systems.

Parameters:

  • toSys (CoordSys) ‚Äì Destination coordinate systems.

rv (RayVector) ‚Äì Rays to transform.

Returns:

transformed (RayVector) ‚Äì Reference to input RayVector transformed in place.

applyForwardArray(x, y, z)[source]ÔÉÅ

Apply forward-direction transformation to ndarrays.

Parameters:

x, y, z (ndarray) ‚Äì Coordinates to transform.

Returns:

xyz (ndarray) ‚Äì Transformed coordinates.

Notes

Unlike applyForward, this method does not transform in-place, but returns a newly created ndarray.

applyReverseArray(x, y, z)[source]ÔÉÅ

Apply reverse-direction transformation to ndarrays.

Parameters:

x, y, z (ndarray) ‚Äì Coordinates to transform.

Returns:

xyz (ndarray) ‚Äì Transformed coordinates.

Notes

Unlike applyReverse, this method does not transform in-place, but returns a newly created ndarray.

Angle ProjectionsÔÉÅ

For exact specification of ray directions, it‚Äôs convenient to use a two-dimensional projection. Batoid includes a number of such projections and deprojections:

batoid.utils.fieldToDirCos(u, v, projection='postel')[source]ÔÉÅ

Convert field angle to direction cosines using specified projection.

Parameters:

  • u, v (float) ‚Äì Tangent plane coordinates in radians.

  • projection ({‚Äòpostel‚Äô, ‚Äòzemax‚Äô, ‚Äògnomonic‚Äô, ‚Äòstereographic‚Äô, ‚Äòlambert‚Äô, ‚Äòorthographic‚Äô}) ‚Äì Projection used to convert field angle to direction cosines.

Returns:

alpha, beta, gamma (float) ‚Äì Direction cosines (unit vector projected onto x, y, z in order)

Notes

The tangent plane reference is at (u,v) = (0,0), which corresponds to (alpha, beta, gamma) = (0, 0, -1) (a ray coming directly from above). The orientation is such that vx (vy) is positive when u (v) is positive.

batoid.utils.dirCosToField(alpha, beta, gamma, projection='postel')[source]ÔÉÅ

Convert direction cosines to field angle using specified projection.

Parameters:

  • alpha, beta, gamma (float) ‚Äì Direction cosines (unit vector projected onto x, y, z in order)

  • projection ({‚Äòpostel‚Äô, ‚Äòzemax‚Äô, ‚Äògnomonic‚Äô, ‚Äòstereographic‚Äô, ‚Äòlambert‚Äô, ‚Äòorthographic‚Äô}) ‚Äì Projection used to convert direction cosines to field angle.

Returns:

u, v (float) ‚Äì Tangent plane coordinates in radians.

Notes

The tangent plane reference is at (u,v) = (0,0), which corresponds to (alpha, beta, gamma) = (0, 0, -1) (a ray coming directly from above). The orientation is such that vx (vy) is positive when u (v) is positive.

Notes

batoid.utils.dirCosToPostel(alpha, beta, gamma)[source]ÔÉÅ

Convert direction cosines to Postel azimuthal equidistant tangent plane projection.

Parameters:

alpha, beta, gamma (float) ‚Äì Direction cosines (unit vector projected onto x, y, z in order)

Returns:

u, v (float) ‚Äì Postel tangent plane coordinates in radians.

Notes

The tangent plane reference is at (u,v) = (0,0), which corresponds to (alpha, beta, gamma) = (0, 0, -1) (a ray coming directly from above). The orientation is such that vx (vy) is positive when u (v) is positive.

batoid.utils.zemaxToDirCos(u, v)[source]ÔÉÅ

Convert Zemax field angles u,v to direction cosines.

Parameters:

u, v (float) ‚Äì Zemax field angles in radians.

Returns:

alpha, beta, gamma (float) ‚Äì Direction cosines (unit vector projected onto x, y, z in order)

Notes

The tangent plane reference is at (u,v) = (0,0), which corresponds to (alpha, beta, gamma) = (0, 0, -1) (a ray coming directly from above). The orientation is such that vx (vy) is positive when u (v) is positive.

The Zemax field angle convention is not rotationally invariant. The z-direction cosine for (u, v) = (0, 1) does not equal the z-direction cosine for (u, v) = (0.6, 0.8).

batoid.utils.dirCosToZemax(alpha, beta, gamma)[source]ÔÉÅ

Parameters:

alpha, beta, gamma (float) ‚Äì Direction cosines (unit vector projected onto x, y, z in order)

u, v (float) ‚Äì Postel tangent plane coordinates in radians.

Notes

The Zemax field angle convention is not rotationally invariant. The z-direction cosine for (u, v) = (0, 1) does not equal the z-direction cosine for (u, v) = (0.6, 0.8).
